name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: [NOISE].

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And here what will do is talk about basic strategy

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: and that would be based on similarity of users and

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _then predicting the rating of an object by a
column6: a

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: active user using the ratings of similar users to this active user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: This is called a memory-based approach because it's a little bit similar to

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: storing all the user information.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And when we are considering a particular user
column6: we're going to try to _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _kind of retrieve the relevant users
column6: or the similar users through this user case. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And then try to use that

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: user's information about those users to predict the preference of this user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So here's the general idea
column6: and we use some notations here

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: X sub i j denotes the rating of object o j by user u i.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And n sub i is average rating of all objects by this user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So this n i is needed.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Because we would like to normalize the ratings of objects by this user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So how do you do normalization?

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Well
column6: where do you adjust that? _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Subtract the
column6: the average rating from all the ratings. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Now this is the normalized ratings so

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: that the ratings from different users will be comparable.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Because some users might be more generous and they generally give more high ratings.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _But
column6: some others might be more critical. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So
column6: their ratings can not be directly compared with each other or _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: aggregated them together.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So
column6: we need to do this normalization. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Now
column6: the prediction of the rating. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _On the item by another user or active user
column6: u sub a here _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: can be based on the average ratings of similar users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So the user u sub a is the user that we are interested in recommending items to.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And we now are interested in recommending this o sub j.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So we're interested in knowing how likely this user will like this object.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: How do we know that?

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Well the idea here is to look at the how whether similar users to this user

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: have liked this object.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So mathematically
column6: this is

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _the predict the rating of this user on this app
column6: object. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: User A on object Oj is basically combination of

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: the normalized ratings of different users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And in fact
column6: here
column7: we're picking a sum of all the users. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But not all users contribute equally to the average.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And this is controlled by the weights.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So this.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Weight controls the inference of a user on the prediction.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And of course
column6: naturally this weight should be related to the similarity _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _between ua and this particular user
column6: ui. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: The more similar they are then the more contribution we would like

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: user u i to make in predicting the preference of u a.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So the formula is extremely simple.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: You're going to see it's a sum of all the possible users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And inside the sum
column6: we have their ratings

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: well their normalized ratings as I just explained.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: The ratings need to be normalized in order to be comfortable with each other.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And then these ratings are rated by their similarity.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So we can imagine a W of A and I is just a similarity of user A user I.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Now
column6: what's k here? _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Well
column6: k is a simpler normalizer. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _It's just it's just one over the sum of all the weights
column6: over all the users. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And so this means
column6: basically
column7: if you consider the weight here together with k. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And we have coefficients or weights that would sum to one for all the users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And it's just a normalization strategy
column6: so that you get this predicted rating _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: in the same range as the these ratings that we use to make the prediction.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Right?

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So
column6: this is basically the main idea of memory-based approaches for _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _collaborative filtering
column6: okay? _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Once we make this prediction
column6: we also would like to map back _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: to the rating that the user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: The user would actually make.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And this is to further add the
column6: mean rating or _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: average rating of this user u sub a to the predicted value.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: This would recover.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: A meaningful rating for this user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So if this user is generous
column6: then the average would be somewhat high

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _and when we added that
column6: the rating will be adjusted to a relatively high rating. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Now
column6: when you recommend an item to a user

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: this actually doesn't really matter because you are interested in basically

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: the normalized rating that's more meaningful.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But when they evaluate these collaborative filtering approach is typically

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: assumed that actual ratings of user on these objects to be unknown.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And then you do the prediction and

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: then you compare the predicted ratings with their actual ratings.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So they
column6: you do have access to the actual ratings. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But then you pretend you don't know.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And then you compare real systems predictions with the actual ratings.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _In that case
column6: obviously the system's prediction would have to be adjusted to _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _match the actual result the user
column6: and this is not what's happening here

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Okay?

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So this is the memory-based approach.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Now of course if you look at the formula

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: if you want to write the program to implement it.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _You still face the problem of determining what is this w function
column6: right? _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Once you know the w function
column6: then the formula is very easy to implement. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So indeed there are many different ways to compute this function or this weight

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And
column6: specific approaches generally differ in how this is computed. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So
column6: here are some possibilities. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And
column6: you can imagine

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: One popular approach is we use the Pearson Correlation Coefficient.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _This would be a sum of a common range of items
column6: and the formula _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _is a standard Pearson correlation coefficient formula
column6: as shown here. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So
column6: this basically measures weather the two users tended _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _to all give higher ratings to similar items
column6: or lower ratings to similar items. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Another measure is the cosine measure and this is the retreat the rating vectors as

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _vectors in the vector space
column6: and then we're going to measure the the angel and _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: compute the cosign of the angle of the two vectors.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And this measure has been used in the vector space more for retrieval as well.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So as you can imagine
column6: there are so many different ways of doing that. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _In all these cases
column6: note that the user similarity is based on their preferences _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _on items
column6: and we did not actually use any content information of these items. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: It didn't matter what these items are.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _They can be movies
column6: they can be books

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _they can be products
column6: they can be tax documents. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: We just didn't care about the content.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And so this allows such approach to be applied to a wide range of problems.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Now in some newer approaches of course

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: we would like to use more information about the user.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Clearly
column6: we know more about the user

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And so in a actual filtering system
column6: using collaborative filtering

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _combine that with content-based filtering
column6: we could use context information. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And those are all interesting approaches that people are still studying.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: There are newer approaches proposed.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But this approach has been shown to work reasonably well and

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: it's easy to implement.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And practical applications could be a starting point to

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: see if the strand here works well for your application.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So there are some obvious ways to also improve this approach.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And mainly would like to improve the user similarity measure.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And there are some practical issues to deal with here as well.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So for example
column6: there will be a lot of missing values. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: What do you do with them?

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _Well
column6: you can set them to default values or the average ratings of the user. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: And that will be a simple solution.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But there are advantages to approaches that can actually try to predict those

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: missing values and then use the predicted values to improve the similarity.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So in fact
column6: the memory database approach

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _you can predict those with missing values
column6: right? _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _So you can imagine

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: you have iterative approach where you first do some preliminary prediction and

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: then you can use the predictor values to further improve the similarity function.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Right so this is here is a way to solve the problem.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And the strategy of this in the effect of the performance of clarity filtering

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _just like in the other heuristics
column6: we improve the similarity function. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Another idea which is actually very similar to the idea of IDF that we

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _have seen in text research
column6: is called the inverse user frequency or IUF. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: Now here the idea is to look at the where the two users share similar ratings.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _If the item is a popular item that has been aah
column6: viewed by many people and _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: seemingly leads to people interested in this item may not be so interesting.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: But if it's a rare item and has not been viewed by many users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _But
column6: these two users [INAUDIBLE] to this item. _

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: _And they give similar ratings
column6: and it says more about their similarity

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: So it's kind of to emphasize more on similarity

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: on items that are not viewed by many users.

name: 5 - 13 - 4.7 Recommender Systems- Collaborative Filtering - Part 2 (00-12-09).srt
text: [MUSIC]
